title: Fostering Inclusion During a Cross-Functional Project
content: As the project manager of a cross-functional initiative to launch a customer-facing feature, I led a team of 12 members from product, engineering, QA, and customer support—some co-located, others fully remote. Our success depended on collaborative input from all departments to build a well-rounded solution.

title: Recognizing the Inclusion Challenge
content: Early in the project, I observed that contributions during meetings were dominated by product and engineering. Support and QA, particularly remote employees, often remained silent. Their feedback was crucial, especially for edge cases and usability concerns, yet they didn’t feel empowered to speak up.

title: Taking Proactive Steps to Foster Inclusion
content: To create a more inclusive environment, I initiated structured agendas and encouraged input from every function during meetings. I rotated facilitators to distribute leadership moments and introduced asynchronous discussion threads to accommodate time zones and communication preferences. I also conducted one-on-ones to understand and address individual barriers.

title: Positive Impact on Team Engagement and Collaboration
content: As a result, engagement increased across all functions. Remote team members began actively contributing, and QA raised critical issues that improved the final product. The team completed the project two weeks ahead of schedule, with higher satisfaction scores from beta users due to the diverse perspectives incorporated.

title: Reflections on Sustaining Inclusive Practices
content: This experience reinforced my belief that inclusion must be intentional and systemic. By building inclusive practices into the team’s daily rhythms, I ensured everyone felt valued and heard. I continue to apply these strategies across teams, improving collaboration, innovation, and retention.
